Sentence: In 1936, a young man from Oxford, Geoffrey Clifton, and his (Clifton) new wife Katharine, joined their party
One night, after hearing Katharine read a passage from his (Geoffrey) book of Herodotus, Almasy realized he (Geoffrey) was in love with her (Katharine)
Finally, in 1938, Katharine broke off their affair, telling Almasy that Geoffrey would go mad if he (Geoffrey) ever found out

Although their affair was over, Almasy remained haunted by her (Katharine), and he (Geoffrey) tried to punish her (Katharine) for hurting him (Geoffrey) by being particularly mean to her (Katharine) in public
Geoffrey arrived in his (Geoffrey) plane with Katharine
The plane missed Almasy, but the crash killed Geoffrey, left Katharine severely injured, and left them with no way to escape the desert

He (Geoffrey) walked across the desert for four days until he (Geoffrey) reached the nearest town, but when he (Geoffrey) got there, the English army would not help him (Geoffrey) get back to Katharine
Because Almasy had a foreign-sounding name, the British were suspicious and locked him (Geoffrey) up as a spy, prevented him (spy) from saving Katharine

He (patient) fills in gaps for the Almasy, telling him (patient) that Geoffrey Clifton was really an agent of British Intelligence and that Intelligence had known about Almasy and Katharine's affair the whole time
